Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Explanation, Decision Making, and Learning in Graphical Models

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Graphical models, such as Bayesian networks and influence diagrams, provide principled approaches to solving reasoning and decision making under uncertainty problems. However, the adaptability and scalability of existing methods for these graphical models are often limited. This project aims to address some of these limitations by developing new and improved approaches to explanation, decision making, and learning in graphical models. It includes the following specific objectives: (1) developing new approaches to finding explanations that only contain the most relevant variables for given observations in Bayesian networks, (2) developing heuristic search-based methods and algorithms to solve influence diagrams more efficiently, (3) developing new algorithms for learning optimal Bayesian networks guided by domain-specific heuristic information so that only a small fraction of the solution space need to be explored, and (4) applying the methods developed in this project to real-world applications including multiple-fault diagnosis, supply chain risk management, and online collaborative learning.

This project can lead to significantly better approaches to reasoning and decision making under uncertainty in many disciplines where graphical models have found successful applications, including medicine, security, planning, business, economics, education, and many others. This project can also lead to the development of new and enhanced courses and curricula, the involvement of students from underrepresented groups in the research, and a wide dissemination of the research outcomes through free software, publications, and presentations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Probabilistic graphical models such as Bayesian networks (BNs) are a successful marriage between graph theory and probability theory; they provide not only compact and intuitive graphical representations of the relations between the random variables in a domain, but also principled approaches to solving reasoning and decision making problems involving uncertainty. Graphical models have proven their value in a broad range of applications. Nevertheless, many challenging issues remain to be addressed in this area of research. The following provides a summary of some of the challenges and our proposed solutions.

 

Most relevant explanations in Bayesian networks 

Bayesian networks provide principled approaches to generating hypotheses about the status of a system for given observations of the system. However, these existing approaches often make unrealistic assumptions about the system in order to be applicable. Some methods assume that target variables are independent and focus only on singleton hypotheses that may be underspecified. Other methods such as MAP and MPE generate multivariate hypotheses that are complete assignments to the target variables; these hypotheses may be overly complex, however.

In a real-world system, typically only a few target variables are most relevant in explaining the given observations. Most Relevant Explanation (MRE) is a new approach we developed to generate “just right” explanatory hypotheses by automatically identifying the most relevant target variables. We have developed both exact and approximation algorithms for solving MRE. More recently our paper describing a hierarchical beam MRE search algorithm has received the best paper award from the FLAIRS-15 conference.

 

Solving realistic influence diagrams using heuristic search

Many problems involve decision making under uncertainty. Influence diagrams provide a natural framework for modeling the relations between random variables, decisions, and preferences; they also provide principled methods for finding a decision policy that maximizes the expected utility. Existing algorithms for solving influence diagrams are mostly based on dynamic programming. These algorithms take a bottom-up approach by solving small lower-level decision problems first and building on the results to solve higher-level problems until finding the solution to the global decision problem. These methods, however, can still be inefficient because they waste computation in solving decision scenarios that are unreachable from an initial state by following an optimal policy.

We have developed an efficient branch and bound algorithm for solving influence diagrams. The idea is to relax an influence diagram such that the resulting model not only is much easier to solve but also provides upper bounds for the original solutions. These bounds are subsequently used in a branch and bound algorithm to find an optimal decision policy by only exploring the most promising decision scenarios. We have shown that the algorithm improves the efficiency of existing algorithms by orders of magnitude while requiring significantly less space.

 

Scaling up learning of optimal Bayesian networks 

Applying Bayesian networks to real-world problems typically requires building graphical representations of the problems at hand. One popular approach is to use score-based methods to find high-scoring structures for given data. Since finding the optimal solution is rather difficult, early research focused mainly on approximation algorithms. Unfortunately, the models found by these methods are not guaranteed to be optimal and, even worse, are of unknown quality. If the results of these approximate models are unsatisfactory, it is hard to determine whether the poor results are due to learning or modeling. Exact learning methods will enable us to focus on modeling issues.

We have developed several efficient algorithms for learning optimal Bayesian networks. One of our main contributions is a new formulation of the learning problem as a shortest-path finding problem. The formulation allows the application of standard heuristic search techniques such as A* to find the solution by only exploring the most promising parts of the search space. We have also developed methods for decomposing the learning problem into several exponentially smaller learning sub-problems and for computing better heuristic functions for guiding the search.

 

Real-world applications 

My expertise in uncertainty reasoning provides me with an excellent foundation to work in interdisciplinary areas. One application we have worked on is supply chain risk analysis. With continued growth in the scope and complexity of global supply chains, supply chain executives have reached deeply into new territories to search for lower costs. As a result, companies are exposed to risks that are far broader in scope and greater in potential impact than before. Identifying and quantifying these risk factors is critical for increasing the efficiency and profitability of these supply chain business processes. I have collaborated with IBM T. J. Watson Research Center in developing a two-dimensional framework for identifying, quantifying, and mitigating risks that affect a company’s global supply chain business processes. The framework has been implemented in a prototype system called Bayesian Supply Chain Risk Analysis and Mitigation (BSCRAM).
